physDesc.p: The letter is four pages long. It is typed on plain paper. The words “Little Review” are written in pencil at the top.

div.p: I have received theSeptember number of the Little Review, and am very glad to see that you printed my two poems in it. I am awfully sorry that you did not get the “London Letter” in time to put it in, as you advertised it to appear, but it was quite out of the question for me to get it off to you any sooner. The conditions prevailing those first weeks in London were not only absolutely against the possibility of writing, but also I literally had not the time to give to it in the press of other and more urgent duties. I got off the letter to you, however, before I sailed for home, and I think that by this time you must have received it.

There are two corrections I should like to make in that article. One is the spelling of the name Henri Regnault, which I know I spelled wrong, and alas I should like to put a star in the footnote after the passage where I say that the English there are lines missing in between the pages
condition has materially changed since the time of writing.
Will you be so kind as to send me a proof of the article?

Three typographical mistakes in the two poems which you printed this month make it most imperative that I should read my own proofs. Indeed it is a thing I always insist upon where it is possible. In “Clear, With Light Variable Winds,” you have changed the order of two of my words. In the line, “Am I not more worth than your day ladies” your version reads, “Am I not worth more,” which is somewhat of a change in meaning, and certainly a very great change in the style. Also, after the “Gemmed with the moon,” there should have been a stanza space which is missing here, and may I suggest that “veil” is not usually spelled “vail?” Nobody knows better than I the woes of proof reading, and therefore I am all indulgence to any errors that may occur, but I must say it is more satisfactory to feel one has committed the blunders oneself, if they must be committed.

May I ask you to send me one copy of the August number of the Little Review. The copy
Whichwhich you so kindly sent me to England, and which I read with so much pleasure, and was most grateful for your kind mention of my poem in the Imagistes Anthology, was siezedseized upon by Richard AdlingtonRichard Aldington, as he was so delighted with your mention of the Imagistes and of him, and he wished to send it to his father. He assured me that I should have it back promptly, and that is the last I have seen of it.

May I make a criticism, a very friendly one, and which seems to me should be made by somebody? Namely, I do not think you should have quoted Flint’s “Swan” in your Augustnumber quite the way you did. You did not acknowledge the fact that it had appeared first both in “Poetry,” and in the Imagistes Anthology, and it looked as if it were appearing for the first time in your magazine as a regular contribution. That, of course, was not quite fair to the other volumes it had appeared in, and Mr. Flint was quite incensed at your putting in no acknowledgements about it, and of course you sentence missing between the pages
time to sue you. Of course Mr. Flint was much pleased at your quoting him, but I think one should try to be on the right legal side in questions of that kind. Forgive this criticism from a well-wisher, and please let me have the proof of the London Letter without delay.

I am, as you see, at my home in Brookline, where everything in the future should be sent. Did I tell you that I have asked Messrs.Macmillan and Company to be so kind as to advertise my new book in your magazine? I know that all advertisements help, and think also that your audience will probably be a friendly one to me.
